fr:mainmatter.fr:p: First, we fix a convention on how to represent natural numbers on a Turing machine. We could, for example, decide to represent them in binary, using the alphabet \{ 0, 1 \}. We denote by \ulcorner n \urcorner the encoding of natural numbers on the tape of the Turing machine.

T_2 is then the following computability model.
The set of type names is \mathsf {T} \vcentcolon \equiv \mathtt {nat}.
\mathbf {C} _{ \mathtt {nat}} \vcentcolon \equiv \mathbb {N} .
The set \mathbf {C} [ \mathtt {nat} , \mathtt {nat} ] contains a function f : \mathbb {N} \rightharpoonup \mathbb {N} if there exists a Turing machine M_f such that, for every natural number n \in \mathbb {N}, if f(n) is defined then when M_f is run on a tape with the encoding \ulcorner n \urcorner on it, it halts in a state where the tape contains the encoding enc{f(n)}.

A computability model consists of the data:
a set \mathsf {T} of type names,
a \mathsf {T}-indexed family of sets ( \mathbf {C} _ \tau )_{ \tau \in T},
for each \sigma , \tau \in \mathsf {T}, a set \mathbf {C} [ \sigma , \tau ] of partial functions f : \mathbf {C} _ \sigma \rightharpoonup \mathbf {C} _ \tau.
These are required to satisfy:
For every \tau \in \mathsf {T}, the identity function \mathrm {id}_ \tau : \mathbf {C} _ \tau \to \mathbf {C} _ \tau is in the set \mathbf {C} [ \tau , \tau ].
For every f \in \mathbf {C} [ \rho , \sigma ] and g \in \mathbf {C} [ \sigma , \tau ], the composition g \circ f is in the set \mathbf {C} [ \rho , \tau ].
